sen.j: カヤノヒメ（カヤヌヒメとも）は、日本神話に登場する草の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: "Kayano-hime" (or Kayanu-hime) is a god of grass (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
"Kayano-hime" (or Kayanu-hime) is a god of grass (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
Kayano-hime (or Kayanu-hime) is a god (Shinto) of grass appearing in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: " "を削除しました。mythology を小文字にしました。

sen.j: 古事記では鹿屋野比売神、日本書紀では草祖草野姫（くさのおやかやのひめ。草祖は草の祖神の意味）と表記し、『古事記』では別名が野椎神（のづちのかみ）であると記している。
sen.e: It is written Kayano-hime (鹿屋野比売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Kusanooyakayano-hime (草祖草野姫. 草祖 means the soshin (ancestor honored as god) of grass) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), and "Kojiki" describes that she had another name, Nozuchi-no-kami.

It is written Kayano-hime (鹿屋野比売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Kusanooyakayano-hime (草祖草野姫. 草祖 means the soshin (ancestor honored as god) of grass) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), and "Kojiki" describes that she had another name, Nozuchi-no-kami.

It is written Kayano-hime (鹿屋野比売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Kusanooyakayano-hime (草祖草野姫; 草祖 means the soshin (ancestor honored as god) of grass) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), and "Kojiki" describes that she had another name, Nozuchi no Kami.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 神産みにおいてイザナギ・イザナミの間に生まれた。
sen.e: She was born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).
She was born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).
She was born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).

sen.j: 『古事記』においては、山の神であるオオヤマツミとの間に、4対8柱の神を生んだ。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," she gave birth to four pairs of eight gods with mountain god, Oyamatsumi.
In "Kojiki," she gave birth to four pairs of eight gods together with the mountain god, Oyamatsumi.
In "Kojiki," she gave birth to four pairs of eight gods together with the mountain god, Oyamatsumi.

sen.j: 神名の「カヤ」はカヤ (草)のことである。
sen.e: Kaya' in the shinmei (name of god) represents kaya (grass).
Kaya' in the shinmei (name of god) represents kaya (grass).
The word 'kaya' in the shinmei (name of god) represents kaya (grass).
sen.cmt: 文頭に一部追加しました。

sen.j: 萱は屋根を葺くのに使われるなど、人間にとって身近な草であり、草の代表として草の神の名前となった。
sen.e: Kaya was a familiar grass for humans, used to thatch roofs, and therefore, became the name of the god of grass, representing grass.
Kaya was a familiar grass for humans, used to thatch roofs, and therefore, became the name of the god of grass, representing grass.
Kaya was a familiar grass for humans, used to thatch roofs, and therefore, became the name of the god of grass, representing grass.

sen.j: 樽前山神社（北海道苫小牧市）では山の神・大山津見神、木の神・ククノチと共に祀られている。
sen.e: At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), she is enshrined together with mountain god, Oyamatsumi-no-kami, and god of trees, Kukunochi.
At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), she is enshrined together with mountain god, Oyamatsumi-no-kami, and god of trees, Kukunochi.
At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), she is enshrined together with mountain god, Oyamatsumi no Kami, and god of trees, Kukunochi.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 萱津神社（愛知県海部郡 (愛知県)甚目寺町）では日本唯一の漬物の神として祀られており、タバコの葉の生産地ではタバコの神として信仰されている。
sen.e: At Kayazu-jinja Shrine (Jimokuji-cho, Ama-gun, Aichi Prefecture), she is enshrined as the only Goddess of pickles in Japan, and is worshipped as the god of tabacco in areas producing tabacco leaves.
At Kayazu-jinja Shrine (Jimokuji-cho, Ama-gun, Aichi Prefecture), she is enshrined as the only Goddess of pickles in Japan, and is worshipped as the god of tabacco in areas producing tabacco leaves.
At Kayazu-jinja Shrine (Jimokuji-cho, Ama-gun, Aichi Prefecture), she is enshrined as the only goddess of pickles in Japan, and is worshipped as the god of tabacco in areas producing tabacco leaves.
sen.cmt: goddes 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 別名の「ノヅチ（野槌）」は「野の精霊（野つ霊）」の意味である。
sen.e: The other name, 'Nozuchi,' means 'spirits in the field.'
The other name, 'Nozuchi,' means 'spirits in the field.'
The other name, 'Nozuchi,' means 'spirits in the field.'

sen.j: しかし、この「ノヅチ」は後にニホンマムシの別名とされるようになり、さらにはヘビの化け物とされるようになった。
sen.e: However, this 'Nozuchi' later became the other name for Japanese copperhead, and furthermore, was considered a monster snake.
However, this 'Nozuchi' later became the other name for Japanese copperhead, and furthermore, was considered a monster snake.
However, this 'Nozuchi' later became the other name for Japanese copperhead, and furthermore, was considered a monster snake.

sen.j: 野槌は、その名前から、頭と尻は同じ大きさで柄のない槌の形をしているとされ、人の足に食いつくとされた。
sen.e: Nozuchi, due to its name, was believed to be shaped like a gripless hammer with a head and bottom similar in size, and would bite on people's feet.
Nozuchi, due to its name, was believed to be shaped like a gripless hammer with a head and bottom similar in size, and would bite on people's feet.
Nozuchi, due to its name, was believed to be shaped like a gripless hammer with a head and bottom similar in size, and would bite on people's feet.

sen.j: ツチノコも蛇の化け物としての野槌から派生したものである。
sen.e: Tsuchinoko also derived from the monster snake, Nozuchi.
Tsuchinoko also derived from the monster snake, Nozuchi.
Tsuchinoko also derived from the monster snake, Nozuchi.
